column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

Cattle numbers remained firm with 385 penned.  It was a plainer yarding with limited numbers offered over the young and grown categories, over half the yarding was made up of cows. All the usual buying group attended in a softer market across the yarding.  Young cattle were to 10c to 25c softer. Grown steers slipped 10c and grown heifers sold from 10c to 30c/kg cheaper and more in places.  Heavy cows were 5c to 15c back, while the light weights sold 20c to 40c/kg softer in places. Heavy bulls sold firm to 10c/kg better. 
 
Young cattle sold to the trade from 250c to 350c, while feeders and restockers paid 298c to 356c for the better bred cattle and 126c to 274c/kg for the plainer secondary types.  Grown Steers made from 300c to 360c, grown heifers sold to the trade from 220c to 374c, while restockers and feeders paid from 180c to 320c/kg. Manufacturing Beef steers made from 260c to 290c and the dairy steers sold from 200c to 282c/kg.
 
Heavy cows sold from 258c to 347c/kg. Medium and light weight cows sold from 100c to 257c/kg.  Dairy cows sold from 120c to 285c/kg. Heavy bulls sold from 240c to 330c/kg.
 
Market Reporter, Sheona Lamb
